qas.question: What is the most frequently employed type of reduction?
What equates to a squared integer according to polynomial time reduction?
What measurement of time is used in polynomial time reduction?
What would need to remain constant in a multiplication algorithm to produce the same outcome whether multiplying or squaring two integers?
According to polynomial time reduction squaring can ultimately be logically reduced to what?
What is the least used type of reduction?

plausible_answers.text: the reduction process takes polynomial time.

qas.question: What is the meaning of polynomial-space reduction?

plausible_answers.text: to the problem of multiplying two integers.

qas.question: What can the problem of dividing an integer be reduced to?
What does one not need to remain constant in a multiplication algorithm to produce the same outcome whether multiplying or squaring two integers?
What is more difficult that multiplication?

context: The most commonly used reduction is a <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>polynomial-time<a0_1/> reduction<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_0/>. This means that <b6_0>the reduction process takes <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>polynomial<a2_1/> time<a2_2/><a2_0/>.<b6_0/> For example, the problem of squaring an integer can be reduced <b7_0>to the problem of <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>multiplying two integers<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>.<b7_0/> This means an algorithm for multiplying two integers can be used to square an integer. Indeed, this can be done by giving the same <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>input<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> to both inputs of the <a4_0>multiplication<a4_0/> algorithm. Thus we see that <b9_0>squaring<b9_0/> is not more difficult than multiplication, since squaring can be reduced to <a4_1><a4_2>multiplication<a4_2/><a4_1/>.
